comments.text:
This was a good video...some of it I'm not sure convinced about.  The 
interesting thing is that recently my mom suffered from takotsubo syndrome 
which is stress induced heart failure.  It was neither a stroke nor heart 
attack; simply heart failure caused by an excessive amount of adrenaline. 
 Hitting a moose in your car is a fairly stressful event in life.  She has 
made a full recovery and will have no longer term damage to her heart or 
any other part of her body.
comments.author: K Rice

top_comment.text:
If all else fails, try playing an instrument. Once you get into it, it's 
all you want to do. I play piano and it relieves me from stress greatly. It 
could be something simple, like learning to play a zylophone. If you're 
feeling eager to try something new, guitar, piano, orchestral instruments, 
or even drums could help fight the stress.﻿

comments.author: iAmEHW

top_comment.text:
*sigh* As a student who is forced to study until 12AM each night, and an 
avid history buff who has been soaked in the cold, unforgiving world of 
endless, arduous, political debate, I can certainly agree that stress is 
harmful. But I find it ridiculous how people use this as a reason why they 
should have a longer vacation from work or less working hours. Think about 
people in China (where my ancestors come from, by the way). They work 12 
hours a day, 7 days a week, make $150 a month, and they don't complain 
nearly as much as you do. Your working conditions are EXTRAVAGANT compared 
to theirs. If you want to reduce your stress on the job, just bear this in 
mind: You are actually VERY lucky compared to the rest of the world.﻿
top_comment.author: FlagArmada Productions

comments.text:
Yes, I do agree that having a positive outlook on everything makes things 
less painful for everybody. For example, Nelson Nandela and Gandhi didn;t 
feel as much pain in prison because they knew they were suffering for a 
good cause.
comments.author: FlagArmada Productions

comments.text:
There are other determining factors that play a huge role of life 
expectancy in relation to stress. Chinese people and Asian people in 
general are more calm and relaxed individuals. The Japanese for example 
have a saying "it cannot be helped" whenever a situation turns sour such as 
someone dying. Besides working extensively, other factors of stress in 
their lives are pretty low because of their positive mentality :) 
Us Americans are all kinds of fucked up when it comes to varying levels of 
stress and what induces stress in out lives. Also, Chinese people eat way 
healthier, thus, better generational genetics which increases life 
expectancy....a million factors

Maybe .... create a perfect imaginary friend take a long time. To reduce, 
the stress , your imaginary friend will change frequently. If you have so

have, can help to reduce your stress level. Face to the social anxiety , 
you should create your internal environment ,your garden and improve your 
analyse of external environment. Sometimes, take a break time, your moment 
of lethargy. Don't stop thinking ! Just take pleasure of the good moment 
,you can have. And solve the situation which will stop your progress or 
your moment of plenitude. It's not an advice. It's my proper experience.

hope to have answered your question.

comments.author: TheHagfish

comments.text:
I was a survivor of child abuse, so my brains ability to handle stress was 
already compromised prior to having children. With severely autistic 
children i experienced severe and chronic stress. Physical symptoms were 
getting sick alot, and getting the flu so bad i couldnt breathe so poor 
immune function, scary heavy periods, altered hormones, unexplained bruises 
all over my body. Mental symptoms of extreme stress were depression, 
anxiety, suicidal and homicidal thoughts, and panic attacks, agoraphobia. 
They tried meds on me and zoloft made it even worse. So byebye kiddos. This 
was 3 years ago. I loved them but that stress was destryoing me. Im lucky i 
made it out alive. Mentally im still traumatized from the experience and 
maybe they are too, separation is terrible for kids but extreme situations 
call for tough decisions. They are in a great therapeutic boarding school 
now.
comments.author: alexandramn

+Felicia L.​ No.. I'm sorry I over reacted. But what you just explained oh

comments.author: Samantha Weatherly

comments.text:
+Samantha Cash
it was a joke but school is stressfull. I live in Sweden but I'm sure 
there's a difference between america and my country. Maybe it isn't 
stressfull if you don't care a shit about what kind of job you'll get, but 
I sure do. My mom didn't have a good education and now we're struggling 
with our economy a lot. Do I want that in the future aswell? God no. Do I 
want to be able to help my mom and poor kids who need it? Oh yes. And you 
have no idea how much my school is pressuring me aswell. I have a stack of 
homework lying on my desk. I don't have time for a social life. I don't 
even have time to go help mom grocery shopping because if I do, I will 
never have a time to relax. And my mom stuggle with epilepsy now since she 
stressed too much at work, and she hated her job aswell. I know what stress 
can cause. There's not a single day in my life that I'm not stressed, not 
even overreacting. Tell me all you want about adult shit. I already do 
adult shit. I clean the house a lot because my mom can't handle getting 
stressed out, clearly. So I will gladly risk my life for her. Because at 
least then I will know that I tried to do something about this. My mom 
didn't deserve to get poor. She just had a bad childhood and she had bad 
parents. It's like I'm her parent anyways. Because I was the one who saved 
her so that she wouldn't die when she got unconscious.

I did not mean to make you upset or anything if that's the case... I just 
want you to understand.
comments.author: Felicia L.

top_comment.text:
It is possible.
a few examples being---

One is that "too much stress" has been known to drive some people to 
suicide (or rampages).
For example, So called "salary men" in japan (or other asian countries) who 
exist under such extreme pressure and stressors that some of them can't 
take it. more examples are "the suicide that snapped under an extreme 
amount of pressure" (suicide) "going postal" (murder/death) "the 
digsruntled employee" (murder/death).

Another is that under too much stress a person may have a blood aneurysm 
and die (where a blood vessel bursts in the head and internal 
hemorrhaging/bleeding ensues. (though this would require a very fine point 
of "too much stress" to happen).

on a final note, stress can cause death as well through things such as high 
blood pressure and in some cases heart failure/attacks.﻿

comments.text:
Stress is a double edged sword.... & can either make you or break you 
depending upon conditioned reflexive proclivities.
We are either objective to stress...or by default subjective to it...one 
way leads to premature death, the other longevity of life.
Stress... is ubiquitous in the universe, there is no escaping it, nor would 
you want to....lest you suffer the stress of no stress.
Gravity is the universal unifying stress, as it is shared by all that 
exists within the confines of the time space continuum. It is AS the spring 
in the universal space time machine that provides the appropriate tension 
required for keeping all clockwork movements in the properly timed unison 
required for the equation of elemental existence to remain balanced.
And just as the complexities of the cosmos requires stress to properly 
function in a balanced fashion, so do we.
 A general fear of stress clearly suggests one has become habitually 
reflexively resentful to stress forces. And resentment of a stress force is 
an unmistakable indicator of subjectivity to a stress source.
Stress, is best not "emotionally fought"... one must learn to approach it 
with objectively receptive thought....like how a Kevlar vest catches a 
bullet.  In this you will learn not just to survive, but thrive.
Patience is the vestment that is called for here...that is, if you value 
life dear.

top_comment.text:
There are many ways to reduce stress in addition to 'cuddling' with 
people... learn to 'cuddle' or care for yourself, by learning to trigger 
the parasympathetic nervous system.... that is the key. Its the sympathetic 
nervous system that becomes over taxed, and runs on overdrive... so... its 
twin, the parasympathetic nervous system is where one must learn to spend 
time. And there our several ways to do this.﻿
top_comment.author: Terry James Williams

comments.text:
Touch... for one. Developing an ever increasing ability and sensitivity 
towards palpation and cuing... I do my own body work, hands on work, on my 
self... The entire body resperates, like a star... heaving contracting and 
expanding. Being able to sense this, ive found, is paramount, in achieving 
a connection with the PSNS... the best place, or easiest place to start, is 
with ones own breath, and getting more and more 'in touch' with the 
diaphragmatic kingdom... its so much more than the 'lungs' proper... more 
even than the rib cylinder... I spend a lot of time teaching people to 
breath again.. how to work out restrictions within the diaphragmatic realm, 
the gut and the pelvic floor... the diaphragm is THE key player, and 
perhaps the most fundamental aspect of health, even the 'core', is strong 
diaphragmatic expression. This is easiest to be picked up and first 
encountered within the lung space... but with practice and patients, and 
attentiveness, one will quickly find 'respiration' to an ever increasing 
extent out away from the spine, and out into the appendages. So breath... 
is one method I use... there are others. But i would start here.
comments.author: Terry James Williams

attentiveness? to what? yourself?

captions.text:
In a busy world, with unending work and responsibilities
piling up, stress can get to the best of us.

But how bad is it for you, really? Can stress
actually kill you?

From a biological perspective, stress makes
perfect sense. If you're about to get chomped

on by a bear, your stress hormones better
kick your butt into gear. But it turns out

that your mortgage, unemployment and looming
exam all trigger the same stress response

in your body. And unlike most animals, which
eventually experience a major decrease in

these hormones, humans can't seem to find
the off switch! Even though it's not life

and death, our psychological woes consistently
bath our bodies in these hormones, making

our heart pound, muscles tense and stomach
turn.

In Japan, they have the term Karoshi, which
literally translates to 'death from overwork'.

In what is now deemed an overworking epidemic,
these individuals who are seemingly healthy

and in their prime, suddenly die. After being
officially recognized and documented in Japan,

these sudden heart attacks and strokes were
quickly linked to stress. But, how does stress
cause this?

Cortisol is one of the main stress hormones,
which helps divert energy to where you need

it and away from nonessential functions of
the body. But with chronic stress exposure,

problems arise: The immune system shuts down,
inflammation is inhibited, white blood cells

are reduced, and susceptibility to disease
increases. Some evidence also suggests that

prolonged stress may be involved in the development
of cancer.

When looking at the arteries of macaque monkeys,
those under significant stress have more clogged

arteries. This prevents blood from getting
to the heart quickly during stress, and can
ultimately lead to heart attacks.

The brain also takes a toll; when looking
at mice exposed to stress, we see dramatically

smaller brain cells, with fewer branch extensions
than normal mice. This is particularly prevalent

in the area associated with memory and learning.
Which may stir up some memories for you of

those wonderful all night study sessions;
the acute stress and sleep deprivation can

make it increasingly difficult to remember
things we want to.

Perhaps the most telling story is in our DNA.
We contain something called telomeres on the

ends of our chromosomes, which decrease in
size with age. Our video on "Aging", here,

explains this process. Eventually, the telomeres
run out, at which point the cell stops duplicating

and dies. So telomeres are directly related
to aging and length of life. And it turns

out, stress may actually accelerate the shortening
of these telomeres.

But not all hope is lost for the perpetually
stressed. Another hormone, oxytocin, has been

shown to reduce this stress response. It helps
your blood vessels relax, and even regenerates

the heart from stress related damage. So how
do we get more Oxytocin? It's sometimes dubbed

the 'cuddle hormone', because it's released
during positive social interactions and while

caring for others. People who spend more time
with others create a buffer or resilience
to stress.

So when life gets the best of you, just remember,
you don't have to go it alone. Spend some

time with those you love - it may just save
your life!
